summary: This is a court order by Judge Alison J. Nathan granting a short continuance of Ghislaine Maxwell's trial from July 2021 to fall 2021. The continuance is granted due to the government's late filing of an S2 Superseding Indictment, which added new charges and an alleged victim, requiring additional defense preparation time. The order balances the defense's need to prepare against the public interest in a timely trial.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, whose defense counsel requested a continuance of the trial date due to a new superseding indictment.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The United States District Judge who issued the order granting a short continuance of Maxwell's trial to fall 2021.

persons.name: Judge Furman
persons.context: A judge presiding over a separate criminal matter involving lawyers who also represent Maxwell, leading to a scheduling conflict mentioned in the order.

connections.description: Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case against defendant Maxwell and issued the order regarding the trial schedule.

events.title: Government Files S2 Superseding Indictment
events.description: The Government filed an S2 Superseding Indictment against Ghislaine Maxwell, adding new charges and extending the timeline of alleged conspiracies.

events.title: Originally Scheduled Trial Start Date
events.description: The trial in the case of United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell was originally scheduled to commence on this date.

events.title: Court Orders Trial Continuance
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issued an order granting a continuance of Maxwell's trial from July 2021 to fall 2021.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The S2 Superseding Indictment extended the timeline of the charged conspiracies from through 1997 to 2004 and identified a fourth alleged victim, referred to as Minor Victim-4.
The S2 Indictment added two new charges: Count 5 (sex trafficking conspiracy between 2001 and 2004) and Count 6 (sex trafficking of a minor or aiding and abetting).
The Court granted a continuance until fall 2021, rejecting both Maxwell's request for a January 2022 date and the Government's proposal for March 2022.
The Court cited the COVID-19 pandemic as hampering defense preparation due to travel constraints and safety concerns.
The order instructs the parties to meet, confer, and jointly propose a new trial start date by May 10, 2021.
